Seairth,

I vote 'yes' to the visible project; 'not sure' to the mail system as the
subject of that project.  Meanwhile, Hao He is trying to get his company
(Thomson Legal & Regulatory) to release on of the REST projects
he did there to open source, for the same purpose.

One way or the other, Mark, I think the 'visible project' thing is
key right now.

Walden


----- Original Message -----
From: "Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
To: "rest-discuss" <rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Friday, January 10, 2003 12:24 AM
Subject: [rest-discuss] pointers and REST promotion...


> I have decided to implement a RESTful "mail" system.  The design I have
come
> up with is incredibly simple, flexible, and (i believe) even RESTful (no,
> really!).  However, before I get too deep into its design, I thought I
would
> look around at what others are doing.  Anyone know of any RESTful (from
the
> ground up, preferably) "mail" systems out there already?
>
>
> In the end, my objective is to get a simple, easily visible RESTful
> application on the web and used by lots of people (the latter part is
> possibly more important that the former part).  As I have been reading the
> "visibility" thread, I got to thinking that (other than letting people
> discover for themselves the pitfalls of RPC) people would be more
receptive
> to REST if they could actually see something RESTful.  I know the Web
itself
> is RESTful, but it's hard to convince someone of the legitimacy of a term
> that came after the application that demonstrated it.  Coming up with
> something *new* would, imho, be an easier thing to digest and understand
to
> the REST skeptics out there.
>
>
> To that end, if anyone is interested in working with me on this, I will
> happily share my thoughts.  I think it's highly workable, and would
> certainly be more successful if it were a group effort.
>
>
> ---
> Seairth Jacobs
> seairth@...
>
>
